EDUC 645 Assignments





1. General Guidelines
The goal of the assignments is to practice the concepts and
vocabulary we have been modeling in class and implement some of the
techniques we have learned. You may work on your own or collaborate with
one (1) partner. Please make sure that you engage in a a full, fair and
mutually-agreeable collaboration if you do choose to collaborate. If you
do collaborate, you should plan, execute and write-up your analyses
together, not simply divide the work. Please make sure to indicate
clearly when your work is joint and any other individual or resource
(outside of class material) you consulted in your responses.
(Here we need to add more details about global expectations and
requirements for all the assignments, grading and points distribution
for participation, assignments, and/or final project/exam, late
submission policy, etc. from syllabus.)


2. Submission format
For each of the four assignments as well as the final project, you
are required to submit two files:
An .doc, .html, or .pdf file that includes your typed responses
(in your own words and not identical to anybody else’s), tables, and/or
figures to the problems
The .Rmd or .R file that you used to render the tables and
figures in the above doc/html/pdf file.


3. Assignments details

3.1. Assignment 1 (Logistic regression)
Objectives:
Using Logistic regression model to estimate a relationship where the
dependent variable is dichotomous
Interpret and report the results and make statistic inference from
the estimated parameters
Deadline: TBD
Assignment description: assignment1.html
Dataset: nscs.csv
Key: [doc file]; [R script]


3.2. Assignment 2 (Poisson regression)
Objectives:
Using Poisson regression model to estimate a relationship where the
dependent variable is a Poisson random variable
Interpret and report the results and make statistic inference from
the estimated parameters
Deadline: TBD
Assignment description: assignment2.html
Dataset: ah_smoke.csv
Key: [doc file]; [R script]


3.3. Assignment 3 (Nested data)
Objectives:
Using mixed-effects model to estimate a relationship when the
clustering nature of data needs to be addressed
Interpret and report the results and make statistic inference from
the estimated parameters
Deadline: TBD
Assignment description: assignment3.html
Dataset: gpa.csv
Key: [doc file]; [R script]


3.4. Assignment 4 (Measurement)
Objectives:


Deadline: TBD
Assignment description:
Dataset:
Key: [doc file]; [R script]


3.5. Final Project
Objectives:


Deadline: TBD
Assignment description:
Dataset:
Key: [doc file]; [R script]

EDUC 645: General Linear Model II
College of Education, University of Oregon





Course Overview
This course is the third and last in the EDUC quantitative method
sequence, which is intended to provide a toolkit of statistical
concepts, methods, and their implementations to producers of applied
research in education and other social sciences.
Pre-requisite: EDUC 641 and EDUC 643. Also a familiarity with
at least one statistical programming language - preferably R language -
is required.


Meeting Time and Location
TBD


Instructors
TBD

EDUC 645
Syllabus

Unit 1: Logistic Regression

      EDUC 645
    
    
      
  Syllabus


  Schedule


  
    Lectures
     
    
  
  
      Unit 1: Logistic Regression
    
    
      Unit 2: Poisson Regression
    
    
      Unit 3: Nested Data Structures
    
    
      Unit 4: Introduction to Measurement and Assessment
    
    
      Unit 5: Cleaning Data & Missing Data
    
  
      
  Assignments


  Course Repo

      
  






EDUC 645 Schedule





Unit 1: Logistic Regression
Learning Objectives:
Introduce the linear probability model and discuss the
limitations
Introduce the concept of probability, odds, and logit
Introduce logistic regression model with continuous predictors
and how to interpret the model parameters and inference for model
parameters
Introduce the glm function in R to fit the logistic regression
model
Introduce the logistic regression model with categorical
predictors and how to interpret the model parameters and inference for
model parameters
Introduce the logistic regression model with an interaction
between a continuous and categorical predictor, how to interpret the
model parameters, and inference for model parameters
Discuss the predictive power, model fit, and diagnostics for a
logistic regression model
Readings:
Lecture:
Lecture slides: html
Dataset: principal.csv
Assignment:
Assignment description: assignment1.html
Dataset: nscs.csv


Unit 2: Poisson Regression
Learning Objectives:
Introduce the count data models
Introduce the concept of rates
Introduce the glm function in R to fit the poisson regression
model
Introduce poisson regression model with continuous predictors and
how to interpret the model parameters and inference for model
parameters
Introduce the poisson regression model with categorical
predictors and how to interpret the model parameters and inference for
model parameters
Introduce the poisson regression model with an interaction
between a continuous and categorical predictor, how to interpret the
model parameters, and inference for model parameters
Discuss dispersion, model fit, and diagnostics for a poisson
regression model
Readings:
Lecture:
Lecture slides: html
Dataset: ceps_sch.csv
Assignment:
Assignment description: assignment2.html
Dataset: ah_smoke.csv


Unit 3: Introduction to Nested Data
Learning Objectives:
Introduce the nested data structure (two-level, e.g., repeated
measures within individuals, students within schools)
Students will be able to understand and explain what
nesting/clustering means

Demonstrate varying intercepts and slopes across clusters. Using
a dataset, students/instructors can fit the same regression model
independently for each cluster and create a table of intercepts and
slopes across clusters
Students will understand what it means for intercepts and slopes to
vary across clusters

Develop/discuss the notion that regression coefficients may vary
across different clusters
Develop the concept of fixed-effects as the
aggregation of the different intercepts and slopes by taking an average
of varying intercept and slopes across clusters
Develop the concept of random effects as the
difference between cluster-specific intercept and slope and their
averages across clusters
Develop the concept of the covariance matrix of
random-effects
Discuss the implications of ignoring the variance of
random-effects in terms of the inference for fixed-effects and
statistical power
Introduce the random intercept-only model, its estimation through
the R lmer package, interpret the model parameters and align them with
the earlier discussion of fixed-effects and random-effects.
Introduce the intra-class correlation as a measure of
within-cluster dependency, and how to use it to decide whether one needs
to use multilevel modeling
Finish by emphasizing that this is a very brief introduction of
nested data and refer students to the multilevel modeling sequence for a
comprehensive treatment of the subject
If time permits, there may be a discussion that not all nested
data needs multilevel modeling and there are alternative approaches to
adjust the standard errors for fixed effects if they are the sole
interest
Readings:
Lecture:
Lecture slides: html
Dataset: seda.csv and portugal.csv
Assignment:
Assignment description: assignment3.html
Dataset: gpa.csv / gpa_above.csv


Unit 4: Introduction to Measurement and Assessment
Learning Objectives:
Introduction to the concept of reliability
Talk about the assumption that there is a single underlying
construct for a set of items in surveys when you aggregate scores across
items
Show how to compute Cronbach’s alpha, how to interpret it, and
emphasize the strong underlying assumptions
Readings:
Lecture:
Lecture slides: html
Dataset:
Assignment:
Assignment description: assignment4.html
Dataset:


Unit 5: Data Cleaning and Handling Missing Data
Learning Objectives:
Students should be ready to talk about the concept of model-based
imputation as earlier lectures in the sequence covered linear regression
and logistic regression
Introduce the missing data mechanisms (MCAR, MAR, MNAR)
Introduce the concepts of the listwise deletion and pairwise
deletion and their potential limitations
Introduce the single-imputation methods (mean, regression, and
stochastic regression imputation)
Introduce the “missing-value-dummy” method (Cohen) and some
issues with this approach
Introduce the conceptual steps for the
multiple-imputation
Introduce the mice package in R and how to implement
multiple-imputation for fitting a regression model to a data set with
missing values
Readings:
Lecture:
Lecture slides: html
Dataset: galo.csv
Assignment:
No assignment for this unit.
Final Project:
Final project description: final.html
Dataset:

EDUC 645: General Linear Model II
Spring 2022





Course Description
You’ll learn stuff in this class, I hope. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas scelerisque elit sapien, eu
consequat dui blandit in. Vestibulum dignissim feugiat mauris, at
pretium turpis blandit nec. Aliquam porta scelerisque tortor, eget
imperdiet quam dapibus et. Sed ut sollicitudin orci, id elementum arcu.
Sed arcu quam, vestibulum molestie mattis sed, ultricies sed est.
Phasellus eu nunc et urna volutpat pharetra. Donec interdum ante vitae
odio malesuada blandit. Fusce at condimentum libero, eu elementum arcu.
Aenean posuere id lorem in varius. Sed bibendum neque pretium dolor
faucibus, in cursus ipsum suscipit. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam erat volutpat. Phasellus mollis
egestas risus, non maximus nisl euismod sit amet. Vestibulum laoreet et
urna vitae rutrum. Donec quis dui elit.


Course Objectives
You’ll learn this
And also that
Perhaps some of this too.


Required Readings


Course Policy
I will detail the policy for this course below. Basically, don’t
cheat and try to learn stuff. Don’t be that guy.

Grading Policy
20% of your grade will be determined by a
midterm during normal class hours.
20% of your grade will be determined by a term
paper that documents your appreciation of Foghat’s “Slow Ride”, the most
important song ever written. “Slow Ride” is what Mozart wishes Don
Giovanni could have been.
10% of your grade will be determined by your
attendance and participation in class. Generally, ask questions and
answer them.
20% of your grade will be determined by a
20-page term paper on when exactly “The Love Boat” jumped the proverbial
shark. You will address whether this shark-jumping can be attributed to
Ted McGinley, the introduction of Jill Whelan as “Vicki”, or some other
cause.
30% of your grade will be determined by a final
exam.


Attendance Policy

Showing up is 80 percent of life – Woody Allen, via
Marshall Brickman Students should be weary of skipping class.



Late Arrival of the Professor Policy
My current university, from what I have been told, asks professors to
have policies written into their syllabus about what students should do
if the professor is more than 15 minutes late to class. This seems like
an anachronism. I will inform students via e-mail in advance of class if
class is cancelled for the day. I will also contact our department
secretary if something happened on the way to work. Failing that, assume
the worst happened to me. I ask the students make sure that my story
gets the proper treatment on an Investigation Discovery show. I
also ask that my story be narrated by Keith Morrison.


E-mail Policy
I am usually quick to respond to student e-mails. However, student
e-mails tend to do several things that try my patience. I have a new
policy, effective Fall 2016, that outlines why I will not respond to
certain e-mails students send. Multiple rationales follow.
The student could answer his/her own inquiry by reading the
syllabus.
The student missed class for which there was no exam. I do not need
to know the exact reason for a missed class. Students with excusable
absences are responsible for giving me a note in hard copy that
documents the reason for the missed class. An e-mail is unnecessary
unless the impromptu absence involved missing a midterm or final.
The student wants to know what topics s/he missed during a class
s/he skipped. The answer is always “you missed what was on the
syllabus.”
The student is protesting a grade without reference to specific
points of objection. See the policy on protesting a grade in the
syllabus. These e-mails tend to be expressive utility on the part of the
student and do not require a response from me. Students interested in
improving their knowledge of material should see me during office
hours.
The students wants to know how many classes s/he missed at some
point during the semester. I assume the student has a better answer to
that question than me until the end of the semester.
The student is requesting an extension on an assignment for which
the syllabus already established the deadline. The answer is always
“no”.
The student is “grade
grubbing” or asking to round up a grade. The answer is always
“no”.
The student is asking for an extra credit opportunity, a request
that amounts to more grading for the professor. The answer is “no”.


Make-Up Exam Policy
There are NO make-ups for missed exams. Don’t bother
asking.


Academic Dishonesty Policy
Don’t cheat. Don’t be that guy. Yes, you. You know exactly what I’m
talking about too.


Disabilities Policy
Federal law mandates the provision of services at the
university-level to qualified students with disabilities. Make sure to
include all that relevant information here.




Class Schedule
Students must read the following before class session. Important:
class readings are subject to change, contingent on mitigating
circumstances and the progress we make as a class. Students are
encouraged to attend lectures and check the course website for
updates.
Taking
Good Notes
Dos
and Dont’s of Writing for Students

Week 01, 03/15 - 03/19: Reviewing GLM and Introduction to Logistic
Regression
Required: * BMLR - Ch. 2 (pp. xx-xx) - 6-6.4 (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended: * BMLR - - 3.3 ‘Discrete Random Variables’
(pp. xx-xx)


Week 02, 03/22 - 03/26: Logistic Regression
Required: * BMLR - 6.5-6.7 (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 03, 03/29 - 04/02: Logistic Regression
Required: * BMLR - (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 04, 04/05 - 04/09: Introduction to Count Data and Poisson
Regression
Required: * BMLR - 4-4.4 (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 05, 04/12 - 04/16: Poisson Regression
Required: * BMLR - 4.5-4.10 (pp. xx-xx) - All of Ch. 5
(pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 06, 04/19 - 04/23: Nested Data
Required: * BMLR - 8-8.5 (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 07, 04/26 - 04/30: Nested Data
Required: * BMLR - 8.6-8.11 (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 08, 05/03 - 05/07: Nested Data
Required: * BMLR - 9-9.7 (pp. xx-xx) - Ch 11
Recommended:


Week 09, 05/10 - 05/14: Measurement Error and Reliability
Required: * BMLR - 7-7.8 (pp. xx-xx)
Recommended:


Week 10, 05/17 - 05/21: Missing Data
Required: *

  Course Repo

      
  






EDUC 645 Syllabus





General Course Information


Course Overview


Student Learning Outcomes


Textbooks and Reading Materials
We will primarily be referring to chapters in Beyond Multiple
Linear Regression (BMLR) by Paul Roback and Julie
Legler. This textbook is available for free online. You may choose to
purchase a paper copy if you wish, but it is not required.

R and RStudio
Students must have the latest version of R, which can be downloaded
here. It is strongly
recommended that students also download the RStudio GUI, available here.
Both softwares are free. We will provide tutorials on R/RStudio
installation and they are also accessible here.

Resources for R and RStudio
While we will teach you how to effectively use R and RStudio to
conduct analyses, one of the key skills required to use R is the ability
to find answers on your own. Many common questions or problems are
either available on blogs or have been asked and answered in discussion
forums already. Finding and deciphering those answers is an important
skill you should seek to hone. You will never remember all of the
programming commands!
Here are some sites where you can find the answers to many R
questions and learn new tricks:
YaRrr, the
Pirate’s Guide to R by Nathaniel Phillips
R for Data Science by
Hadley Wickham
R Cookbook by
Winston Chang
An Introduction to
Statistical Learning by Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor
Hastie and Robert Tibshirani
Cheat
Sheets
Quick-R
StackOverflow
Stack Exchange




Schedule
For more details, see here.
Units
Unit Topics
Weeks
Lecture Topics
Lab Objectives
Required Readings
Recommended Readings
Assignments
Quizzes
1
Logistic Regression
1
a. Review OLS
a. R basics and R packages







b. Dichotomous outcomes
b. Visualize/describe dichotomous data when explanatory
variables are continuous, categorical, and interactions
BMLR Ch. 2 (pp. xx-xx), 6-6.4 (pp. xx-xx)





2
a. Interpreting logistic regression coefficients
a. Logistic regression programming in R
BMLR Ch. 6.5-6.7 (pp. xx-xx)






b. Significan testing and model fit







3
a. Diagnostics
a. Logistic regression programming in R (cont’d)







b. Classification and accuracy
b. Preview Unit 1 assignment/quiz


Assignment 1 (Due: TBD)
Quiz 1 (Due: TBD)

a. Count data and probability
a. Review Unit 1 assignment/quiz
BMLR Ch.4-4.4 (pp. xx-xx)






b. Poisson regression analysis
b. Visualize/understand Poisson data

a. Coefficient estimation and interpretation
a. Poisson regression programming in R
BMLR Ch. 4.5-4.10 (pp. xx-xx) Ch. 5 (pp. xx-xx)

Assignment 3 (Due: TBD)

BMLR Ch. 7-7.8 (pp. xx-xx)

Data cleaning and handling missing data

b. Dealing with missing data in R


No assignment
Quiz 5 (Due: TBD)

Final
11




Final Project



Grading Components and Criteria
Final grades will be based on the following components:
Quizzes: 20% (5 quizzes 4% each)
Assignments: 60% (5 assignments, 12% each)
Final: 20%

Quizzes
Five classes will begin with a very short multiple-choice quiz that
is designed to test your knowledge of the theoretical principles
underlying the statistics we are studying for the week. While some may
feel that this is overly paternalistic, research evidence shows that
frequent quizzing increases learning (see a summary of one
study from the University of Texas). Quizzes will be open book and
notes (but not laptop/computer).


Assignments
The goal of the assignments is to practice the concepts and
vocabulary we have been modeling in class and implement some of the
techniques we have learned. Each assignment has an associated data
source, short codebook and detailed instructions for the required data
and analytic tasks. You may work on your own or collaborate with one (1)
partner. Please make sure that you engage in a a full, fair and
mutually-agreeable collaboration if you do choose to collaborate. If you
do collaborate, you should plan, execute and write-up your analyses
together, not simply divide the work. Please make sure to indicate
clearly when your work is joint and any other individual or resource
(outside of class material) you consulted in your response. Further
assignment details are available here.


Final



Student Engagement Inventory
Graduate students are expected to perform work of high quality and
quantity, typically with forty hours of student engagement for each
student credit hour. For this course, the following table shows the
number of hours a typical student would expect to spend in each of the
following activities:
Educational activity
Hours
Explanatory comments
Class attendance
30
Three hours per week over 10 weeks
Class reading and prep
30
Includes reading and review of slides
Homework Assignments
25
Five assignments taking 5 hours each (on avg.)
Quizzes
5
One hour per quiz
Labs
10
One hour-long lab per week over 10 weeks
Final
20
Includes familiarization with data, data analysis, preparation of
displays and writing
Total hours
120
These are approximations. Reading and
especially analytic time will vary per individual
